title.narrative: Mechanism 16772 - NDOH (CDC GH001172)

description.narrative:
Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
The goal of the cooperative agreement with the NODH is to implement evidence-based public health programs, surveillance and disease control, and prevention activities. PEPFAR funds will support the NDOH to incorporate results of program evaluations into operational disease prevention and control programs, ensure the sharing of expertise and lessons learned nationally, regionally and internationall Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.15: Biomedical Prevention - Medical Male Circumcision. Policy, training, outreach, message development, service delivery, quality assurance, and equipment and commodities related to male circumcision (MC). Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.12: Laboratory Infrastructure. Development and strengthening of laboratory systems and facilities to support HIV/AIDSrelated activities including purchase of equipment and commodities and provision of quality assurance, staff training and other technical assistance. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.10: Treatment/ARV Drugs. This includes procurement, delivery and in-freight of ARV drugs. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.2: Sexual Prevention - Abstinence/Be Faithful. Activities (including training) to promote abstinence, fidelity, reducing multiple and concurrent partners, and related social and community norms that impact these behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.13: Health System Strengthening. Include activities that contribute to national, regional or district level systems by supporting finance, leadership and governance (include broad policy reform efforts including stigma, gender, etc.), institutional capacity building, supply chain or procurement systems, Global Fund programs and donor coordination. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

The goal of the cooperative agreement with the NODH is to implement evidence-based public health programs, surveillance and disease control, and prevention activities. PEPFAR funds will support the NDOH to incorporate results of program evaluations into operational disease prevention and control programs, ensure the sharing of expertise and lessons learned nationally, regionally and internationally, and use the results to develop science-based health policies and guidelines. Funds will be used to pay for staff to implement the vision of the PFIP. CDC activities will be integrated within NDOH operational plans for HIV and TB prevention, care, treatment, strategic information, laboratory systems strengthening, and health systems strengthening. PEPFAR-funded activities include staff, pre-service and in-service training, development of guidelines and tools, and surveys (e.g. TB and DHS). Geographic coverage is national, supporting activities in all nine provinces. Target population varies across activities, but largely focuses on DOH staff from facility level to national. Since the activities supported through the coag are not service delivery as such, the question on cost-efficiency is not relevant as such. As PEPFAR funding decreases, the NDOH will have to budget for ongoing costs. Many of the activities are once off and would not require ongoing funding. M&E of NDOH supported activities has been a challenge. The NDOH will be hiring staff to specifically support programs in strengthening their M&E plans for supported activities. Several activities do have plans such as the progress in the roll out of the Tier ART. NDOH has significant pipeline, which is why little FY 14 funds have been budgeted.

policy-marker.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. government's response to the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and represents the largest commitment by any nation to address a single disease in history.

title.narrative: This area of the State Department website contains the standard terms and conditions documents incorporated by reference into all standard grants, cooperative agreements, fixed amount awards, award to individuals, and property awards to U.S. and foreign recipients that are not Foreign Public Entities.
Contains listing of PEPFAR reports, including Financial Management
The additional data section contains budget datasets that can be downloaded. These datasets replace the previous budget PDF files.
This dataset contains mechanism-level COP budget data for COP20-COP21 using PEPFAR Financial Classifications.
This section of the PEPFAR website contains various budget, target and results information in Strategic Direction Summaries, Approval Memos and Planning Level Letters

This dataset contains mechanism-level targets and results for Fiscal Years (FY) 2018 - 2022 (starting October 2017 through the latest quarter’s data.
